page.title: 10N. Gen. Hospital, Sheffield
page.content: The Northern General evolved from a workhouse founded in 1878. Today it is a large Teaching Hospital of 1006 beds plus Psychiatric & Mental Handicap Units. In 1984 Admissions were 28910, A&E cases 59228, Outpatients 111464 and live births 2458. It is the only hospital in Britain to perform laser angioplasty, a technique pioneered by Dr. David Cumberland during 1984/5 to clear blocked arteries. It has been performed in the legs of about 20 patients so far. Under local anaesthetic a laser beam is directed down a tube and used to burn away fatty deposits caused by disease. Formerly this was done by inflating a balloon in the artery or by surgery. Laser angioplasty may eventually be used as a cheaper, quicker and safer alternative to open heart surgery.
